keyPolicies.policyTitle: A Brexit to Protect Working People
keyPolicies.policyDescription: Labour believes the first priority of Brexit negotiations should be to protect jobs and workers' hard-won rights.
Labour advocates for a fully costed plan to put 10,000 additional police officers on the beat throughout the country.
Labour intends to make SATs optional, change to the National Funding Formula and invest in schools. The party advocates reducing class sizes to under 30 for all five, six, and seven-year-olds.

issues.brexitEurope: Labour strongly believes the priority for Britain's Brexit negotiations should be to protect jobs and workers' rights.
issues.economy: Criticism of the Tory approach; mention of zero hour contracts, stagnant wages, and threats to pensions amid the economy discussions.
issues.education: Labour wants to make SATs optional, change the National Funding Formula, invest in schools, and ensure class sizes are under 30 for young children.
issues.governance: Criticism of the 'Tory approach' suggesting a Labour perspective that seeks to make a positive difference without resorting to the status quo.

leaflet.personalStatement: "I’m very proud to have been selected by the Labour and Cooperative Party as the candidate for Peterborough. This is my home; regard this campaign as an opportunity to stand up for the city."

politicalExperience.role: Spokesperson for Children, Young People, and Families

contactInformation.address: Norwich House, Oxney Road, Peterborough PE1 5YW

images.caption: Fiona Onasanya at the street stall
More officers on the beat must be a priority
Must challenge every policy the Tory party introduce to ensure they are designed to benefit themselves.
